home.title: Welcome to the Barnet FC Homecoming BA Workshop!
home.intro: This interactive session is designed to give you hands-on experience applying key Business Analysis frameworks to a realistic scenario.

goal.title: Workshop Goal:
goal.text: To collaboratively analyze Barnet FC's planned return to their home borough, using PESTLE, Stakeholder Analysis, and CATWOE, fostering critical thinking and shared learning.

agenda.title: Today's Game Plan (Agenda)
items: Section 1: External Environment – PESTLE Analysis (20 mins)
Section 2: Understanding the Players – Stakeholder Analysis (20 mins)
Section 3: Deep Dive – CATWOE Analysis (20 mins)

scenario.title: The Scenario: Barnet FC – The Bees' Return
paragraphs: Barnet FC, affectionately known as "The Bees," boasts a rich history, having played at their iconic Underhill Stadium in the London Borough of Barnet for 106 years. In 2013, due to various constraints with Underhill, the club relocated to The Hive Stadium in the neighboring borough of Harrow. While The Hive has served as a functional home, the emotional and historical ties to Barnet remain strong amongst the fanbase and local community.

After a decade away, Barnet FC's leadership has announced an ambitious strategic initiative: to return to the London Borough of Barnet by developing a new, purpose-built stadium. This project, with an estimated budget of £25 million and a proposed 3-year timeline, is more than just a construction project; it's a symbol of homecoming, community regeneration, and a new chapter for the club, which currently competes in the National League (the fifth tier of English football).

The move is fraught with complexities: securing planning permissions, community engagement, financial viability, managing supporter expectations, and ensuring the new stadium meets modern standards while respecting the club's heritage. Success will depend on meticulous planning, robust analysis, and effective stakeholder management.

pestle.title: Section 1: PESTLE Analysis (20 mins)
pestle.objective: To identify and analyze the key external macro-environmental factors that could influence Barnet FC's stadium relocation project.
pestle.task: In your teams, brainstorm and document factors under each PESTLE category. Identify at least 2-3 distinct factors per category, explaining their potential impact. Use your flip chart or digital whiteboard.

items.name: Political
promptingQuestions: How might local council elections or changes in political leadership impact planning permissions?
What national government policies on sports infrastructure or funding could affect the project?
items.challengingFactor: A newly elected local council has a manifesto commitment to prioritize social housing over large leisure developments.

items.name: Economic
promptingQuestions: How might the current economic climate (inflation, construction costs) impact the £25 million budget?
What are potential economic benefits for the local Barnet area?
items.challengingFactor: A major local employer announces significant layoffs, reducing disposable income.

items.name: Social
promptingQuestions: What is the current sentiment of the Barnet community towards the club's return?
How might demographic shifts influence stadium design/services?
Are there concerns about disruption, traffic, or noise?
items.challengingFactor: A vocal residents' group emerges, concerned about impact on local parkland.

items.name: Technological
promptingQuestions: What modern stadium technologies should be considered (cashless, Wi-Fi, sustainability)?
How can technology enhance fan engagement?
items.challengingFactor: The proposed site has poor existing digital infrastructure.

items.name: Legal
promptingQuestions: What are key planning permission requirements and potential legal hurdles?
Are there specific safety/accessibility regulations for new sports venues?
items.challengingFactor: An ancient right of way is discovered across a section of the proposed land.

items.name: Environmental
promptingQuestions: What are environmental considerations (green building, waste, wildlife)?
How can the club demonstrate commitment to sustainability?
items.challengingFactor: The proposed site is adjacent to a protected nature reserve.

stakeholders.title: Section 2: Stakeholder Analysis (20 mins)
stakeholders.objective: To identify key stakeholders, understand their perspectives, and prioritize them based on their influence and interest.
activitySteps: Map each stakeholder on an Interest/Influence Grid (use your provided template or draw one).
Prioritize: Identify your Top 3 Critical Stakeholders.
Briefly discuss engagement approaches for these top 3.

personas.name: Sarah Chen (Local Resident)
personas.interests: Quiet neighborhood, property values, minimal disruption.

personas.name: David Miller (Barnet FC CEO)
personas.interests: Successful relocation, financial viability, club legacy.

personas.name: Cllr. James Wilson (Barnet Council Leader)
personas.interests: Economic regeneration, job creation, positive council image.
personas.concerns: Public backlash, project failure, strain on services.

personas.name: Mark Jenkins (Long-time Season Ticket Holder)
personas.interests: Club returning home, match-day experience, club success.

personas.name: Fatima Ahmed (Local Business Owner)
personas.concerns: Increased local business rates, construction disruption.

personas.name: Maria Sanchez (National League Rep)
personas.interests: Compliance with ground grading, club stability.

personas.name: Kevin Beale (Construction PM)
personas.concerns: Unforeseen conditions, supply chain, scope creep.

grid.title: Interest/Influence Grid:
grid.description: Use your handout or draw a 2x2 grid. Label axes "Interest" (Low to High) and "Influence" (Low to High). Plot stakeholders into:
categories: High Influence / High Interest: Manage Closely
High Influence / Low Interest: Keep Satisfied
Low Influence / High Interest: Keep Informed
grid.reminder: Remember to identify your Top 3 critical stakeholders for the next section!

twists.title: Sudden Funding Shortfall!
twists.description: A key private investor (£5M) has pulled out due to unforeseen financial difficulties. The project is now significantly underfunded. How does this impact the timeline, scope, and stakeholder confidence? What are immediate priorities?

twists.title: Discovery of Archaeological Significance!
twists.description: During initial site surveys, potential Roman-era artifacts are discovered on a portion of the proposed stadium land. This could lead to significant delays for assessment and potential redesigns. How does this affect the project plan and community relations?

twists.title: Rival Club Announces Competing Development!
twists.description: A nearby football club announces its own plans for a major stadium upgrade, potentially competing for local resources, sponsorships, and fan attention. How does this change the strategic importance and urgency of Barnet FC's return?

twists.title: Unexpected Promotion!
twists.description: Against all odds, Barnet FC achieves promotion to a higher league! This means new league requirements for stadium capacity and facilities, potentially impacting the current design and budget. Is this a good problem to have, or a major new challenge?

twists.title: Key Land Parcel Unavailable!
twists.description: A crucial piece of land needed for the stadium's access road is suddenly tied up in a complex legal dispute, making its acquisition uncertain for the foreseeable future. What alternative access plans can be considered? How does this impact the overall feasibility?

catwoe.title: Section 3: CATWOE Analysis (20 mins)
catwoe.objective: To analyze the perspectives and needs of your Top 3 critical stakeholders, providing deeper understanding for requirements elicitation.The primary purpose of CATWOE is to provide a structured way to think about a problem or a proposed change by ensuring all relevant perspectives are considered. It is particularly useful in the early stages of a project or when analyzing complex business situations with multiple stakeholders who may have conflicting interests. By identifying and understanding these different elements, organizations can gain a clearer picture of a situation, facilitate better communication among stakeholders, and make more informed decisions.
catwoe.task: For EACH of your Top 3 stakeholders identified in the previous section, conduct a CATWOE analysis using your template/whiteboard.

items.name: Customers/Clients
items.description: Who benefits or suffers from the transformation (from this stakeholder's POV)?

items.name: Actors
items.description: Who carries out the activities in the transformation (from this stakeholder's POV)?

items.name: Transformation Process
items.description: What's the core change? (Input -> Output, e.g., undeveloped land -> community asset).

items.name: Weltanschauung/Worldview
items.description: What's the stakeholder's core belief making this meaningful? (e.g., "Barnet FC belongs in Barnet").

items.name: Owners
items.description: Who has ultimate authority to approve/stop it (from this stakeholder's POV)?

items.name: Environmental Constraints
items.description: What external factors impact it? (Link to PESTLE).

example.title: Example Questions (for David Miller, Barnet FC CEO):
questions: C: Who ultimately benefits if this relocation is a success from his perspective? Who suffers if it fails?
W: What's his core belief driving this? ("A new stadium is essential for the club's long-term survival and growth").

presentations.title: Team Presentations & Discussion (15 mins)
presentations.intro: Each team will have 3-4 minutes to share key insights.

focus.title: Presentation Focus:
items: Your Top 3 critical stakeholders and why.
Key insights from one CATWOE analysis.
One major challenge or "aha!" moment (and impact of the twist, if applicable).

discussionPrompts.title: Discussion Prompts:
items: What were the most common critical stakeholders identified? Why?
Which PESTLE factor seemed most impactful across teams?
How do these analyses help in a real project?

header.title: The Analyst's Toolkit
header.subtitle: From abstract challenges to actionable insights. A guide to the foundational frameworks that power successful business analysis.

pestle.title: PESTLE
pestle.subtitle: The 'Wide-Angle Lens'
pestle.description: This framework forces us to look beyond our immediate tasks to understand the external, big-picture forces that will impact our work, ensuring our solutions are resilient and relevant.

stakeholderAnalysis.title: Stakeholder Analysis
stakeholderAnalysis.subtitle: The 'People Map'
stakeholderAnalysis.description: A systematic way to identify everyone with a stake in our project. By mapping their interest and influence, we can tailor communication and prevent late-game surprises.

catwoe.title: CATWOE
catwoe.subtitle: The 'Empathy Tool'
catwoe.description: Allows us to step into our stakeholders' shoes and see the business problem from multiple, distinct perspectives, ensuring we solve the right problem for the right people.

flowchartSection.title: From Insight to Impact
flowchartSection.description: These frameworks are not isolated exercises. They are the essential first step, feeding critical insights directly into subsequent BA activities.

points.title: Understand the Context
points.description: PESTLE ensures your solution is relevant and resilient against external forces.

points.title: Understand the Stakeholders
points.description: Stakeholder Analysis ensures your solution will be supported and accepted.

points.title: Understand the Perspectives
points.description: CATWOE ensures the solution you build is the one people actually need.

collaborationSection.title: The Collaboration Multiplier
collaborationSection.description: These frameworks achieve their true power when used collaboratively. Bringing people together uncovers blind spots, challenges assumptions, and builds the shared understanding needed for project success from day one.
